paper.title: Increased Protection Versus the Cost of Increased Protection: Victimization and the Use of Protective Measures Against Identity Theft
paper.abstract: Most identity theft victims experience no personal monetary loss or other financial problems; rational choice theory suggests that this could lead people to not change their behavior, increasing their future risk of victimization. Consequently, the current study will investigate if and how the severity and incidence of identity theft affect individuals' protective behavior using the 2016 Identity Theft Supplement (ITS) victimization survey. It uses ordinary least squares (OLS) regression to predict the number of protective measures practiced and multinomial logistic regression to predict self-reported motivation for use of protective measures. The results indicate that victims use more protective measures than nonvictims and that victimization has a greater impact if it occurs repeatedly and/or the victims personally lost money or experienced other financial problems. However, there is evidence of a threshold effect. The multinomial results indicate victims who lost money or experienced other financial problems are more likely to say they practice protective measures because of their victimization.

domain_result.justification: 该论文主要研究身份盗窃受害者的保护行为及其影响因素，虽然涉及金融问题（如个人金钱损失），但其核心研究内容并不属于衍生品定价、金融风险管理或投资组合管理中的任何一个领域。
